Welcome to my personal page! I am a PhD Candidate in the Dept. of Statistical Science at Duke University working with David B. Dunson and Surya T. Tokdar. Broadly speaking, I am interested in the intersection between Bayesian Inference and Probabilistic Machine Learning. Currently, I am working on Bayesian Factor Models and Nonparametric Density Estimation.
In October ‚Äò21, I completed a MSc in Data Science at Bocconi University advised by Giacomo Zanella, with a thesis on stochastic gradient MCMC.

summary: Stochastic Gradient (SG) Markov Chain Monte Carlo algorithms (MCMC) are popular algorithms for Bayesian sampling in the presence of large datasets. However, they come with little theoretical guarantees and assessing their empirical performances is non-trivial. In such context, it is crucial to develop algorithms that are robust to the choice of hyperparameters and to gradients heterogeneity since, in practice, both the choice of step-size and behaviour of target gradients induce hard-to-control  biases in the invariant distribution. In this work we introduce the stochastic gradient Barker dynamics (SGBD) algorithm, extending the recently developed Barker MCMC scheme, a robust alternative to Langevin-based sampling algorithms, to the stochastic gradient framework. We characterize the impact of stochastic gradients on the Barker transition mechanism and develop a bias-corrected version that, under suitable assumptions, eliminates the error due to the gradient noise in the proposal. We illustrate the performance on a number of high-dimensional examples, showing that SGBD is more robust to hyperparameter tuning and to irregular behavior of the target gradients compared to the popular stochastic gradient Langevin dynamics algorithm.
title: Robust Approximate Sampling via Stochastic Gradient Barker Dynamics

summary: We propose Bayesian Kernel Similarity for Supervised Dimensionality Reduction (BKS$^2$DR). BKS$^2$DR learns an easily interpretable low-dimensional representation of the covariates that is predictive of a response variable. Our method is free of any distributional assumptions and is able to capture non-linear dependencies between the covariates and the response. We design a new loss, which penalizes each low-dimensional representation by the distance of its Gram matrix from the response Gram matrix, constructed using a positive-definite Kernel, and adopt a loss-based approach characterizing uncertainty via the resulting Gibbs posterior distribution. The learned low-dimensional representation can be used for a downstream regression task, avoiding the issues of estimating a model in the original, high-dimensional space.We validate our method through extensive simulations showcasing its robustness to heavy-tailed noise in high-dimensional and moderate-sample size scenarios.We apply our method to an environmental epidemiology dataset, highlighting the ability to reduce dimensionality in modeling complex exposure effects while maintaining interpretability and predictive accuracy.
title: Generalized Bayes Kernel Similarity for Supervised Dimensionality Reduction
